body: how would you detect that a file is temporary?

There is a special method which identifies files as temporary while it's scanning the folder. All it does is matches the name against a certain pattern.
On windows is `~syncthing~<filename>.tmp` I think, on unix it's `.syncthing.<filename>` or something like that.

This is where the content of the files goes as they are being downloaded.
Once the download is complete, the old file (which had the old content) is overwritten with the temp file, making the change 'atomic'.

@calmh what do you think would be the best way to do this?
If we were to replace Request with hash rather than file/offset/size it would perhaps make it easier.
Then we perhaps just hold a separate block index for temp files...
And then ask everybody for a given hash in a random order hoping to spread the load and have as much distribution as possible?

Please also reuse blocks/parts from files in `.stversions`, this would save a lot of time/bandwidth - e.g. both devices use staggered file versioning. Device A deletes a file and on device B it's moved to `.stversions`. Later device A copies the same file again to the sync folder (maybe a different subfolder). To allow easier identification of these "temporary" files the versioning suffix could be changed to "~syncthing~YYYYMMDD-HHMM" instead of "~YYYYMMDD-HHMM"

I don't think that this is possible as we simply are not tracking indexes of these files,
unlike the temp files where we already know what content they hold as we are pulling them.

issue.title: Protocol changes before v1.0

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New features or improvements of some kind, as opposed to a problem (bug)

labels.name: protocol
labels.description: Issues that require a change to the protocol (BEP, relay, discovery)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
I'd like to propose the following changes and reasons why I think these would be useful:

Discovery:
1. Address - add a integer to indicate the protocol over which the client is listening, or alternatively, ideally replace addresses with a `[]string` then sending full URLs with arbitrary amount of information, such as `dst://123.123.123.123:22002/?certname=pulse`

BEP:
1. Request - Add hash of the block being requested - So that in the future we could verify that the block we've read matches the hash, and to do block lookups by hash.
2. Request - Add `[]Options` for general extensibility
3. Folder - Add `[]Options` for general extensibility (and in the future perhaps sending some verification to the receiver to indicate that we hold the correct encryption key for that folder)
4. IndexMessage - Add `[]Options` for general extensibility (and in the future perhaps sending a signature over the IndexMessage if the folder is encrypted to verify that we have the correct key hence other party should accept our index update)
5. Probably some new derivative of IndexMessage required for #950 
6. Some better response mechanism for Requests (to indicate that we don't have the block anymore for example)

issue.title: A file I deleted during transfer leaves errant ~syncthing~.{filename}.tmp

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
What happened:
I started syncing a file, then deleted it from the sending host.  The partial file remains on the receiving host as a ~syncthing~.{filename}.tmp file.

What did you expect to happen instead of what did happen, if it's not crazy obvious:
Delete the .tmp file when the file is deleted, however, this then might break "Allow partial downloads to be available for pulling" #950...  

Perhaps if the file is currently transferring or _hasn't_ been marked "Deleted," (in the case where either node goes offline during transfer or there is other network connectivity issues) retain the tmp file (to allow resume)?  If the file _has_ been marked "Deleted" from the sender, then delete the tmp file?

What operating system, operating system version and version of Syncthing you are running:
Receiver: Windows Server 2012 R2
Sender: Windows 8.1 Pro
